metadata.case_name: Electricity Board of Rajasthan v. Mohan Lal

facts.text: Electricity Board of Rajasthan constituted on 1st July, 1957, under the Electricity Supply Act, 1948 (No. 54 of 1948).
Before constitution of the Board, supply of electricity in Rajasthan controlled by Electrical and Mechanical Department of State Government.
Respondent No. 1 Mohan Lal and respondents 4 to 14 were permanent employees of State Government as Foremen in Electrical and Mechanical Department.

Services of employees including respondents provisionally placed at disposal of Board by Government notification on 12th February, 1958, under section 78A of Act 54 of 1948. Direction to Board to frame new grades and service conditions; employees to opt to accept new or continue existing (except conduct and disciplinary rules) or claim pension/gratuity.
Board did not frame any new grades and service conditions up to time of litigation.
Respondent No. 1 deputed by State Government to Public Works Department on 27th January, 1960, after working under Board for about two years.
Government order dated 10th August, 1960, treated respondent No. 1 and respondents 4 to 14 as on deputation to the Board.
Public Works Department order dated 24th November, 1962, reverting respondent No. 1 to parent department from 1st December, 1962; period extended till 25th July, 1963.
Respondent No. 1 actually reverted to Board on 11th July, 1963; Board posted him as Foreman.
While respondent No. 1 in Public Works Department, respondents 4 to 14 promoted by Board as Assistant Engineers; respondent No. 1 promoted as Assistant Engineer in Public Works Department.
On reversion, respondent No. 1 claimed promotion as Assistant Engineer under Board (juniors promoted) or to be considered; request turned down by Board and State Government.
Respondent No. 1 filed writ petition under Articles 226 and 227 in Rajasthan High Court claiming equality with respondents 4 to 14, violation of Articles 14 and 16.

High Court rejected Board's contentions, quashed promotions of respondents 4 to 14, directed Board to consider promotions afresh including respondent No. 1's claim. Judgment dated May 14, 1965 in D.B. Civil Miscellaneous Writ Petition No. 469 of 1963.
Board appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.
In deputation order to Public Works, respondent No. 1 to retain lien in Power Department (held by High Court to mean Board).
Reversion order from Public Works treated Board as parent department.

legal_issues.text: Whether respondent No. 1 was a permanent employee of the Board entitled to be considered for promotion along with respondents 4 to 14.
Whether the Electricity Board of Rajasthan is 'State' as defined in Article 12 of the Constitution, amenable to writ jurisdiction under Articles 226/227 for violation of Articles 14 and 16.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent No. 1 never became permanent servant of Board, held no substantive post, could not claim promotion.
Board not 'State' under Article 12; autonomous corporate body for commercial activities; 'other authorities' ejusdem generis with governments/legislatures/local authorities.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 12; Electricity Supply Act, 1948; precedents: University of Madras v. Shantha Bai, B. Devadas v. Tile Selection Committee, Krishan Gopal Ram Chand Sharma v. Punjab University

respondent_arguments.text: Entitled to equality of treatment with respondents 4 to 14 under Articles 14 and 16; Board failed to consider for promotion.
Continued as servant of State throughout, retained lien; alternatively, if transferred to Board, identical position to others.

court_reasoning.text: Respondent No. 1 treated as Board employee by Government and Board (deputation, lien in Power Department=Board, reversion to parent=Board, posting by Board); identical to respondents 4-14 who were promoted despite provisional transfer; no new grades framed, so old conditions apply; entitled to consideration for promotion equally.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Both parties treated respondents as Board employees despite provisional transfer.

court_reasoning.text: 'Other authorities' in Article 12 not ejusdem generis (no common genus in named bodies); includes statutory bodies with governmental/quasi-governmental functions, even commercial; Board has sovereign powers (directions punishable criminally).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ejusdem generis inapplicable; wide amplitude per Ujjam Bai, Ramamurthi Reddiar.

court_reasoning.text: Shah J. concurs Board is 'State' (sovereign powers delegated); but not every statutory authority is 'State'â€”must share sovereign power to impose restrictions on fundamental rights.

holdings.text: Respondent No. 1 is employee of Board, governed by same conditions as respondents 4-14, entitled to be considered for promotion equally.
Electricity Board of Rajasthan is 'authority'/'State' under Article 12; Part III applies.

precedents_cited.case_name: University of Madras v. Shantha Bai
precedents_cited.relevance: Held university not 'authority' ejusdem generis; court rejects ejusdem generis.

precedents_cited.case_name: B. Devadas v. Tile Selection Committee
precedents_cited.relevance: Authorities exercise governmental power; court rejects narrow view.

precedents_cited.case_name: Krishan Gopal Ram Chand Sharma v. Punjab University
Smt. Ujjam Bai v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Other authorities' wide, includes statutory bodies administering laws.

precedents_cited.case_name: K.S. Ramamurthi Reddiar v. Chief Commissioner, Pondicherry
precedents_cited.relevance: Includes all authorities within territory, even autonomous.

precedents_cited.case_name: United Towns Electric Co. Ltd. v. Attorney-General for Newfoundland

statutes_cited.name: Electricity (Supply) Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Government placed services at Board's disposal provisionally.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Board is 'State'/authority under Art 12; violation of 14/16; writ jurisdiction; State can carry trade.

outcome.summary: Appeal against Rajasthan High Court order dismissed; High Court upheld respondent No. 1's claim, quashed promotions of respondents 4-14, directed fresh consideration including respondent No. 1.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court's direction affirmed: consider promotions afresh taking into account respondent No. 1's claim.

key_quotes.text: 'Other authorities' is wide enough to include within it every authority created by a statute and functioning within the territory of India.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of Article 12, holding Board is 'State'.

key_quotes.text: The doctrine of ejusdem generis could not, therefore, be applied to the interpretation of the expression 'other authorities' in this article.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The Board is an authority invested by statute with certain sovereign powers of the State.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Shah J.'s concurrence on Board as 'State'.
